First, despite the question mark at the end, your sentence is really a statement. Anyway... Hip Hop (like Jazz and Blues before it) began as an African American form. Its roots come from African American and Caribbean culture (Jamacian toasting, playing the dozens, the spoken word poetry of artists like Gil Scott Heron, the music of James Brown and George Clinton, etc.) "Rap" itself was an African American slang term for talking ("Sit down and rap awhile, man"). Because of his habit of including extended spoken "sermons" in his songs (such as "Hold What You Got"), '60s soul singer Joe Tex was known as "The Rapper". It's therefore only natural that many of the most prominent hip hop artists are black (as is also the case with jazz, blues, and R&B). But, of course, race/color has nothing to do with talent or ability. Just as there have always been great white jazz musicians (going all the way back to Bix Biederbecke), there are also plenty of exceptional rappers of all ethnic backgrounds (Eminem and the Beastie Boys, to name but two).
